datafield.subfield: Equilibrium and Sudden Events in Chemical Evolution

We present new analytic solutions for one-zone (fully mixed) chemical evolution models that incorporate a realistic delay time distribution for Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia) and can therefore track the separate evolution of α-elements produced by core collapse supernovae (CCSNe) and iron peak elements synthesized in both CCSNe and SNe Ia. Our solutions allow constant, exponential, or linear–exponential (${{te}}^{-t/{\tau }_{\mathrm{sfh}}}$) star formation histories, or combinations thereof. In generic cases, α and iron abundances evolve to an equilibrium at which element production is balanced by metal consumption and gas dilution, instead of continuing to increase over time. The equilibrium absolute abundances depend principally on supernova yields and the outflow mass loading parameter η, while the equilibrium abundance ratio $[\alpha /\mathrm{Fe}]$ depends mainly on yields and secondarily on star formation history. A stellar population can be metal-poor either because it has not yet evolved to equilibrium or because high outflow efficiency makes the equilibrium abundance itself low. Systems with ongoing gas accretion develop metallicity distribution functions (MDFs) that are sharply peaked, while “gas starved” systems with rapidly declining star formation, such as the conventional “closed box” model, have broadly peaked MDFs. A burst of star formation that consumes a significant fraction of a system’s available gas and retains its metals can temporarily boost $[\alpha /\mathrm{Fe}]$ by 0.1–0.3 dex, a possible origin for rare, α-enhanced stars with intermediate age and/or high metallicity. Other sudden transitions in system properties can produce surprising behavior, including backward evolution of a stellar population from high to low metallicity.
Department of Astronomy - The Ohio State U. - Columbus - OH 43210 - USA
Department of Physics and Astronomy - U. of Pittsburgh - Pittsburgh - PA - USA
Department of Astronomy - The Ohio State U. - Columbus - OH 43210 - USA
{m}_{{\rm{O}}}^{\mathrm{cc}}, the mass of newly produced oxgyen returned to the ISM by CCSNe per unit mass of star formation
{m}_{\mathrm{Fe}}^{\mathrm{cc}}, the mass of newly produced iron returned to the ISM by CCSNe per unit mass of star formation, and
{m}_{\mathrm{Fe}}^{\mathrm{Ia}}, mass of newly produced iron returned to the ISM by SNe Ia per unit mass of star formation
\eta ={\dot{M}}_{\mathrm{outflow}}/{\dot{M}}_{* }, the mass loading factor, to be the ratio of gas mass ejected from the ISM by stellar feedback to the gas mass being incorporated into stars, and
r, the recycling parameter, to be the fraction of mass formed into stars that is returned from the envelopes of CCSN progenitors and AGB stars at its original metallicity
{\tau }_{* }={M}_{g}/{\dot{M}}_{* }, the SFE timescale, to be the ratio of the current ISM gas mass Mg to the instantaneous SFR {\dot{M}}_{* }, and
{\tau }_{\mathrm{dep}}={\tau }_{* }/(1+\eta -r), the gas depletion timescale, to be the net rate at which gas is being depleted by the combination of star formation and outflows

Under fairly general conditions, the abundances in a one-zone model with constant parameters evolve to an equilibrium in which the production of new metals is balanced by the combination of dilution and loss of metals to star formation and outflows. If the SFR is approximately constant, then oxygen approaches equilibrium on the gas depletion timescale {\tau }_{\mathrm{dep}}={\tau }_{* }/(1+\eta -r), while iron approaches equilibrium on the gas depletion or SN Ia timescale ({\tau }_{\mathrm{Ia}}\approx 1.5\,\mathrm{Gyr}), whichever is longer

At early times (t\ll {\tau }_{\mathrm{Ia}}) the [{\rm{O}}/\mathrm{Fe}] ratio is determined by CCSN yields, {Z}_{{\rm{O}}}/{Z}_{\mathrm{Fe}}={m}_{{\rm{O}}}^{\mathrm{cc}}/{m}_{\mathrm{Fe}}^{\mathrm{cc}}. For constant SFR, the equilibrium abundances at late times are {Z}_{{\rm{O}}}={m}_{{\rm{O}}}^{\mathrm{cc}}/(1+\eta -r) and {Z}_{\mathrm{Fe}}=({m}_{\mathrm{Fe}}^{\mathrm{cc}}+{m}_{\mathrm{Fe}}^{\mathrm{Ia}})

/(1+\eta -r), with strong dependence on η. The equilibrium abundance ratio is {Z}_{{\rm{O}}}/{Z}_{\mathrm{Fe}}={m}_{{\rm{O}}}^{\mathrm{cc}}/({m}_{\mathrm{Fe}}^{\mathrm{cc}}+{m}_{\mathrm{Fe}}^{\mathrm{Ia}}), depending only on yields. Declining SFHs lead to higher equilibrium abundances and lower equilibrium [{\rm{O}}/\mathrm{Fe}]

Elevated [{\rm{O}}/\mathrm{Fe}] ratios are a sign that the iron abundance, at least, has not yet reached equilibrium. Conversely, models with approximately solar or sub-solar [{\rm{O}}/\mathrm{Fe}] are usually close to equilibrium in [\mathrm{Fe}/{\rm{H}}]. It is difficult to construct a model with constant parameters that shows significant increase in [\mathrm{Fe}/{\rm{H}}] after reaching near-solar [{\rm{O}}/\mathrm{Fe}]
an extremely long gas depletion timescale is required

A population can be low metallicity either because it has not had time to evolve to equilibrium or because the equilibrium abundance itself is low. Different factors may dominate in different situations, and both may be important in some cases. For example, gas-rich dwarf galaxies may be metal-poor because of low SFEs (large {\tau }_{* }), so that they remain below equilibrium, and dwarf spheroidal galaxies may have had their star formation truncated before reaching equilibrium. However, when star formation is vigorous the timescale for achieving equilibrium can be short, and many high-redshift galaxies may be low metallicity not because they are young but because they have high outflow rates that keep their equilibrium abundances low. Metallicity gradients in galaxies could arise from slower star formation (departure from equilibrium) or higher outflow efficiency (low equilibrium abundance) at larger radii. Mixing processes, not included in our models, may also play an important role in regulating gradients (e.g., Schönrich & Binney,: #apjaa580cbib69

The behavior of one-zone models can be significantly different if the SFR is declining on a timescale {\tau }_{\mathrm{sfh}} that is comparable to the depletion timescale {\tau }_{\mathrm{dep}} or, for iron, to the SN Ia timescale {\tau }_{\mathrm{Ia}}. A value of {\tau }_{\mathrm{sfh}}\approx {\tau }_{\mathrm{dep}} arises when the system is i.e., when the rate of gas accretion is much lower than the rate of gas depletion. In these cases the equilibrium abundances become large because metals are deposited in a rapidly declining gas supply, but the timescale to reach equilibrium becomes long

Models with exponential ({\dot{M}}_{* }\propto {e}^{-t/{\tau }_{\mathrm{sfh}}}) and linear-exponential ({\dot{M}}_{* }\propto {{te}}^{-t/{\tau }_{\mathrm{sfh}}}) SFHs have the same equilibrium abundances, but the early-time abundances are a factor of two lower for linear-exponential histories, and the approach to equilibrium is considerably slower. In either case, a more rapidly declining SFH (shorter {\tau }_{\mathrm{sfh}}) leads to lower [{\rm{O}}/\mathrm{Fe}] at equilibrium because the delayed SN Ia enrichment, which comes from an earlier time when star formation was more rapid, is more important compared to ongoing CCSN enrichment

When {\tau }_{\mathrm{sfh}}\gg {\tau }_{\mathrm{dep}} and {\tau }_{\mathrm{sfh}}\gg {\tau }_{\mathrm{Ia}}, a generic situation for a system with ongoing gas accretion, MDFs are sharply peaked near the equilibrium abundance. The limiting case of constant SFR has {dN}/{{dZ}}_{{\rm{O}}}\propto {(1-{Z}_{{\rm{O}}}/{Z}_{{\rm{O}},\mathrm{eq}})}^{-1} up to the current abundance {Z}_{{\rm{O}}}(t). For oxygen, {\tau }_{\mathrm{sfh}}=2{\tau }_{\mathrm{dep}} is a critical case with constant {dN}/{{dZ}}_{{\rm{O}}}, and shorter {\tau }_{\mathrm{sfh}} produces declining {dN}/{{dZ}}_{{\rm{O}}}. The traditional or scenarios represent the limiting case of no gas accretion, yielding {\tau }_{\mathrm{sfh}}={\tau }_{\mathrm{dep}}, and this produces an exponential MDF {dN}/{{dZ}}_{{\rm{O}}}\propto \exp [-{Z}_{{\rm{O}}}(1+\eta )/{m}_{{\rm{O}}}^{\mathrm{cc}}]. However, these scenarios do not capture the typical behavior for star-forming systems with continuing accretion

Similar considerations apply to iron MDFs, but here the relevant comparison timescale is usually {\tau }_{\mathrm{Ia}} rather than {\tau }_{\mathrm{dep}}. A system with rapid accretion and rapid depletion can produce a rising {dN}/{{dZ}}_{{\rm{O}}} and a declining {dN}/{{dZ}}_{\mathrm{Fe}} if the timescales are such that 2{\tau }_{\mathrm{dep}}\lesssim {\tau }_{\mathrm{sfh}}\lesssim 2{\tau }_{\mathrm{Ia}}. While the MDF shapes of α-elements and iron-peak elements should typically be similar in form, cases where they differ can provide a distinctive diagnostic of enrichment timescales

At early times (t\ll {\tau }_{\mathrm{dep}} and t\ll {\tau }_{\mathrm{Ia}}) and low metallicities, exponential SFHs produce constant dN/dZ and linear-exponential SFHs produce {dN}/{dZ}\propto Z, given our assumptions of constant {\tau }_{* } and metallicity-independent yields. This behavior is sensitive to our assumption of instantaneous recycling of CCSN products

Bursts of star formation, on the scale of an entire galaxy or of an individual molecular cloud or star-forming region, boost the rate of CCSN enrichment relative to SN Ia enrichment. If the CCSN products are retained by the system, then a burst that converts a significant fraction of the available gas into stars can easily boost [{\rm{O}}/\mathrm{Fe}] by 0.1-0.3 dex. The low observed scatter in [{\rm{O}}/\mathrm{Fe}] at fixed [\mathrm{Fe}/{\rm{H}}] (along either the or sequences) sets limits on the importance of this time-varying enrichment effect. In typical molecular clouds, it is probably small because of low conversion efficiency, and perhaps because the CCSN metals are lost before they can be incorporated into new stars. However, molecular clouds vary in their properties, and occasional systems that form stars efficiently and retain their metals could be a source of rare α-enhanced stars at intermediate ages : #apjaa580cbib11

: #apjaa580cbib48). Bursty SFHs in dwarf galaxies could have a significant impact on their [{\rm{O}}/\mathrm{Fe}] distributions, relative to smooth SFHs with the same time-averaged behavior (Gilmore & Wyse, 1991: #apjaa580cbib26)

A rapid change from efficient star formation (short {\tau }_{* }) to inefficient star formation (long {\tau }_{* }) can lead to a substantial drop in [{\rm{O}}/\mathrm{Fe}], as iron deposition exceeds oxygen deposition. Conversely, a rapid change from low to high efficiency leads to a temporary boost in [{\rm{O}}/\mathrm{Fe}]

One can produce an evolutionary sequence that has increasing [\mathrm{Fe}/{\rm{H}}] at low [{\rm{O}}/\mathrm{Fe}] by decreasing η, and thus raising the equilibrium abundance itself, after the population has already evolved to an initial equilibrium. Alternatively, by increasing the outflow efficiency at late times, one can construct an evolutionary track that reaches solar [{\rm{O}}/\mathrm{Fe}] and [\mathrm{Fe}/{\rm{H}}] and then moves backward to lower [\mathrm{Fe}/{\rm{H}}] at constant [{\rm{O}}/\mathrm{Fe}] because of the reduction in equilibrium abundance. This backward evolution scenario allows a single evolutionary track to produce a bimodal distribution in the [{\rm{O}}/\mathrm{Fe}]-[\mathrm{Fe}/{\rm{H}}] plane

In any one-zone model, all α elements, by which we mean elements produced entirely by CCSNe with a metallicity-independent yield, follow the same track in [{\rm{X}}/\mathrm{Fe}] versus [\mathrm{Fe}/{\rm{H}}], described by Equation (, 42: #apjaa580ceqn42). In particular, the drop between the CCSN plateau and the eventual equilibrium [{\rm{X}}/\mathrm{Fe}] is the same for all such elements. When an observed element does not show this behavior, it indicates that there is another significant source (SN Ia or AGB production), or that the IMF-averaged net yield is metallicity dependent, or that the observational estimates of the abundance are systematically biased

any one of these would be an interesting conclusion. Elements like sulfur that have a subdominant but non-negligible contribution from SNe Ia should show intermediate behavior, as described by Equation (, 109: #apjaa580ceqn109). Detailed comparisons of the [{\rm{X}}/\mathrm{Fe}] tracks of different α-elements should provide significant insights on their production mechanisms. Even when yields have weak metallicity dependence at a fixed stellar mass, the IMF-averaged net yield could change with metallicity either because the IMF itself changes or because the mass ranges of stars that explode as CCSNe (instead of collapsing to black holes) change with metallicity

Beyond these insights, we expect our analytic solutions to have significant practical utility for modeling observations. The key equations are (, 50: #apjaa580ceqn50), (, 52: #apjaa580ceqn52), (, 53: #apjaa580ceqn53) for oxygen, CCSN iron, and SN Ia iron evolution with an exponential SFH and the corresponding Equations (, 56: #apjaa580ceqn56)-(, 58: #apjaa580ceqn58) for linear-exponential SFHs. Sections, 4.2: #apjaa580cs4-2 and, 5: #apjaa580cs5 describe a variety of ways to extend these results, including more complex SFH, double-exponential DTDs for SNe Ia, models with discontinuous parameter changes, and α-elements with significant SN Ia contributions. Analytic solutions enable rapid explorations of parameter space, zeroing in on regions of observational or physical interest that merit detailed numerical modeling. They are useful for characterizing degeneracies among parameters, to better understand whether a fit to data is unique or one among many. In more quantitative terms, their speed of calculation makes them useful for statistical modeling of data sets via likelihood methods, Markov chain Monte Carlo sampling, or related techniques (e.g 2013: #apjaa580cbib36). While most systems of interest are more complicated than a one-zone model, some may be usefully approximated by mixtures of one-zone models, or by a one-zone model whose geometry and kinematics change over time to represent heating or contraction.These models are aimed principally at the interpretation of resolved stellar populations with star-by-star abundance measurements. They may also be useful for modeling gas phase abundances and connecting them to underlying stellar populations, an application of growing importance in the era of large IFU surveys such as CALIFA Sánchez et al 2012: #apjaa580cbib65), SAMI Croom et al 2012: #apjaa580cbib16), and MaNGA Bundy et al : #apjaa580cbib10). They can also be incorporated into population synthesis models of galactic spectral energy distributions, tying a distribution of stellar metallicities to an inferred history of star formation. They can be used as an approximate tool for post-processing numerical simulations to make chemical evolution predictions in simulations that do not explicitly track multi-element enrichment.The high-fiber revolution that transformed the study of large-scale structure is now transforming our knowledge of the multi-element distributions of stellar populations in the Milky Way and its neighbors. These rich data sets, often augmented by phase space information from astrometry and age information from asteroseismology, offer many clues to the history of our Galaxy. One of the challenges in interpreting these clues is evaluating the uniqueness of successful models, especially in light of systematic uncertainties in element yields and the observed abundances themselves. Flexible approximate models can play a valuable role in mapping out the variety of routes to a given final state and identifying the observational features that may best distinguish competing scenarios.Appendix C provides a step-by-step guide to using our analytic results for computing enrichment histories, [\alpha /\mathrm{Fe}] tracks, and MDFs

Choose values for the supernova yield parameters {m}_{{\rm{O}}}^{\mathrm{cc}}, {m}_{\mathrm{Fe}}^{\mathrm{cc}}, and {m}_{\mathrm{Fe}}^{\mathrm{Ia}}. The default values listed in Table, 1: #apjaa580ct1 are reasonable choices, based on the assumptions described in Section, 2.2: #apjaa580cs2-2
Choose a value of the mass recycling parameter r. Our fiducial value r = 0.4 is a good choice for a Kroupa IMF, and results are only weakly sensitive to this parameter

Choose values for the solar oxygen and iron abundance. To convert from the conventional shifted number density scale {x}_{i}\equiv 12+\mathrm{log}({{\rm{X}}}_{i}/{\rm{H}}) to mass fractions use \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}\mathrm{log}{Z}_{{\rm{O}},\odot } & = & ({x}_{{\rm{O}}}-12)+\mathrm{log}(16)+\mathrm{log}(0.71)\\ & = & -2.25+({x}_{{\rm{O}}}-8.69),\end{eqnarray} \end{align*}
\end{equation*} where we have adopted a solar hydrogen mass fraction of 0.71 and an atomic weight of 55.85 for iron
Choose values for the SN Ia DTD timescale {\tau }_{\mathrm{Ia}} and the minimum delay time {t}_{D}. Our fiducial values are {\tau }_{\mathrm{Ia}}=1.5\,\mathrm{Gyr} and {t}_{D}=0.15\,\mathrm{Gyr}
Specify values of the mass-loading parameter η, the SFE timescale {\tau }_{* }, and the e-folding timescale for the SFR, {\tau }_{\mathrm{sfh}}

Calculate the depletion timescale {\tau }_{\mathrm{dep}}={\tau }_{* }/(1+\eta -r). Calculate the harmonic difference timescales {\bar{\tau }}_{[\mathrm{dep},\mathrm{sfh}]}, {\bar{\tau }}_{[\mathrm{dep},\mathrm{Ia}]}, and {\bar{\tau }}_{[\mathrm{Ia},\mathrm{sfh}]} from Equation (, 23: #apjaa580ceqn23). If you will be exploring many parameter values, it may be useful to multiply {\tau }_{* }, {\tau }_{\mathrm{sfh}}, and {\tau }_{\mathrm{Ia}} by numbers that are very slightly different from one to avoid exact equalities that lead to undefined values of the harmonic difference timescales. As discussed in the text, abundance results are convergent and physical even near limits where one of these timescales diverges

Compute the equilibrium abundances {Z}_{{\rm{O}},\mathrm{eq}}, {Z}_{\mathrm{Fe},\mathrm{eq}}^{\mathrm{cc}}, and {Z}_{\mathrm{Fe},\mathrm{eq}}^{\mathrm{Ia}} from Equations (, 28: #apjaa580ceqn28)-(, 30: #apjaa580ceqn30)
Choose an exponential or linear-exponential SFH. By setting {\tau }_{\mathrm{sfh}} to a large value, one can also use these cases to approximate a constant SFR or linearly rising SFR, respectively

Compute {Z}_{{\rm{O}}}(t) and {Z}_{\mathrm{Fe}}(t)={Z}_{\mathrm{Fe}}^{\mathrm{cc}}(t)+{Z}_{\mathrm{Fe}}^{\mathrm{Ia}}(t) using Equations (, 50: #apjaa580ceqn50), (, 52: #apjaa580ceqn52), and (, 53: #apjaa580ceqn53) for an exponential SFH or Equations (, 56: #apjaa580ceqn56)-(, 58: #apjaa580ceqn58) for a linear-exponential SFH. These can be converted to [{\rm{O}}/{\rm{H}}]=\mathrm{log}({Z}_{{\rm{O}}}/{Z}_{{\rm{O}},\odot })-\mathrm{log}(X/{X}_{\odot }), [\mathrm{Fe}/{\rm{H}}]=\mathrm{log}({Z}_{\mathrm{Fe}}/{Z}_{\mathrm{Fe},\odot })\mbox{--}\mathrm{log}(X/{X}_{\odot }), where {X}_{\odot } is the solar hydrogen fraction, and [{\rm{O}}/\mathrm{Fe}]=[{\rm{O}}/{\rm{H}}]-[\mathrm{Fe}/{\rm{H}}]

To compute an iron MDF, first choose bins for [\mathrm{Fe}/{\rm{H}}]. Then compute {Z}_{\mathrm{Fe}}(t) with a constant time spacing and add a quantity proportional to {\dot{M}}_{* }(t), and hence to the number of stars formed during the time interval, to the [\mathrm{Fe}/{\rm{H}}] bin in which {Z}_{\mathrm{Fe}}(t) falls. The resulting histogram can be multiplied by a constant to normalize it to unit integral. Short time spacings (e.g., 0.002\,\mathrm{Gyr}) may be necessary to get accurate and smooth results at low metallicity

Distributions of [{\rm{O}}/\mathrm{Fe}] and [{\rm{O}}/{\rm{H}}] can be computed in the same way as the iron MDF. Equations (, 62: #apjaa580ceqn62) and (, 63: #apjaa580ceqn63) provide analytic forms for the oxygen MDF for a constant or exponential SFH, respectively
To model a more general SFH that is a sum of exponentials and/or linear-exponentials, follow Equation (, 117: #apjaa580ceqn117)

The analytic results for {Z}_{\mathrm{Fe}}^{\mathrm{Ia}} are computed using Equation (, 53: #apjaa580ceqn53) after multiplying {m}_{\mathrm{Fe}}^{\mathrm{Ia}} by (0.478,0.522) for \tau =(0.5,5)\,\mathrm{Gyr} in the {t}_{d}=0.15\,\mathrm{Gyr} case, and by (0.493,0.507) for \tau =(0.25,3.5)\,\mathrm{Gyr} in the {t}_{d}=0.05\,\mathrm{Gyr} case. These multiplicative factors are not exactly (0.5,0.5) because we normalize the two exponentials to produce the same number of SNe Ia over 12.5\,\mathrm{Gyr}, while {m}_{\mathrm{Fe}}^{\mathrm{Ia}} is defined out to t=\infty
Note that {t}^{-1.1} is critically different from {({\rm{\Delta }}t)}^{-1.1}, which would imply an infinite number of SNe Ia for any {t}_{D}

We tabulate oxygen and iron abundances as a function of time from the analytic results and compute SFR-weighted mean values by numerical integration, then convert to the logarithmic quantities \langle [\mathrm{Fe}/{\rm{H}}]\rangle and \langle [{\rm{O}}/\mathrm{Fe}]\rangle
